page.title: 14TRIMINGHAM
page.content: Trimingham is one of the highest points in Norfolk. Although the cliffs are about 70 meters high access to the shore is possible down the 'bomb disposal' gangway. The highest part of The Beacon was used as a Radar Station during the 2nd World War, the beaches were mined to protect the station and as they took many years to clear the gangway was named after the disposal regiment. The Radar instalations were removed and the land sold, but the main area has once more been aquired by the Ministry of Defence _ it is now secret but shows little sign of use. The village itself straggles along the coast. It is slowly decreasing in acerage as the cliffs break up and topple into the sea. Farming and tourism are the only industries, people commute to work.
